abstract.p: Five Days column; US reached free trade agreement with South Korea; deal, if ratified by Congress, means cheaper Hyundai and Kia cars for American consumers; US agreed to lift 2.5 percent tariffs on South Korean cars; deal will also remove South Korea's 8 percent import duty on cars; photo (S)

block.p: The United States reached a free trade agreement with South Korea, its biggest since the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico.

The deal, if ratified by Congress, means cheaper Hyundai and Kia cars for American consumers; Washington agreed to lift 2.5 percent tariffs on South Korean cars. The deal will also remove South Korea's 8 percent import duty on cars and phase out heavier tariffs on beef and oranges, helping American car companies, ranchers and farmers expand in South Korea, where consumers are developing a taste for foreign goods.
The United States reached a free trade agreement with South Korea, its biggest since the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico.

The deal, if ratified by Congress, means cheaper Hyundai and Kia cars for American consumers; Washington agreed to lift 2.5 percent tariffs on South Korean cars. The deal will also remove South Korea's 8 percent import duty on cars and phase out heavier tariffs on beef and oranges, helping American car companies, ranchers and farmers expand in South Korea, where consumers are developing a taste for foreign goods.

American cattle farmers, kicked out of the South Korean beef market three years ago after an outbreak of mad cow disease, lobbied for an immediate re-entry. That wish was not fulfilled during the trade talks.

In coming months, each government faces the task of persuading its legislature to agree to the pact, which they say will add $20 billion to bilateral trade. They will continue to talk, meanwhile, on whether, and how fast, South Korea should lift its ban on American beef.
